awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The US/France/Belgium iREU Site in Translational Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites Program of the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Randolph S. Duran recruits cohorts of students, primarily selected from the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) in STEM Program, which has sites nationwide. The students who become members of this International Research Experiences for Undergraduates (iREU) Site conduct summer research in France and Belgium. The goal is to provide deep scientific and cultural immersion learning experiences during which participants obtain publication-quality results. Strong translational infrastructure, such as innovation campuses at each location, gives participants exposure to how research discoveries can lead to start-up companies in this international setting. 

This iREU Site focuses on the chemical aspects of sophisticated nanoscience and biotechnology, giving students an early experience at bridging the gap between basic research and emerging applications. The unique and close interactions among university research, high technology companies, and national laboratories provide students the opportunities to experience a network of research not typically available to students at their home institutions. The facilities, from high-tech scale-up to international user facilities, are also different from many research universities in the United States. Students with previous experience and a strong desire to continue in STEM areas are recruited, with emphasis on NSF-LSAMP Programs nationwide. The international collaborators show institution commitment by developing a way to credit iREU students with the equivalent of European Master's degrees, based on performance. Outstanding facilities and research support at the proposed locations ensure sufficient resources for participants.

por.por_cntn:
Experiences of a lifetime were created for 40 undergraduate students recruited from across the US providing research opportunities ranging from 3 months to 6 months in outstanding French research laboratories.  Photo “1” shows a brief summary of this program which has been on-going for over 20 years, along with select participants from the program. Each of the European host locations: the Institute Pasteur de Lille, France; University of Grenoble-Alpes, France; IMEC (Leuven) Belgium, University of Bordeaux and University of Toulouse, France; has a world-class university that provided our high quality participants many outstanding experiences that often led to continued education in graduate or medical school.  For example, the 2016 cohort participant Gabriela Correa was accepted into Cornell University and won an NSF GRFP award; participant Lacey Douglas went onto graduate school in inorganic chemistry at Texas A&M University; and participant Rashid Chatani became a graduate student at Worcester Polytechnic University.  The REU participants also had meaningful cultural experiences to complement their research, for instance, photo “2” shows Xavier student Lydia Mensah at the United Nations who has since graduated with her chemistry Ph.D. from the University of Michigan.

     One of the most exciting examples is Mr Anthony Keyes of the 2017 cohort who became the “first-ever” international REU student to perform the equivalent internship of the European “M2” master’s degree.  Shown in photo “3”, Anthony Keyes, a chemistry major from Jackson State University and MS LSAMP accomplished the first European master’s equivalent internship, defending his research entitled “Optimization of Polyol Synthesis for Production of Magnetic Iron Oxide Nanoparticles Grafted with a Thermosensitive Drug Linker” at the University of Bordeaux in June 2017, and is a 2017 NSF GRFP awardee. More examples from the 2017 cohort include Julian Smith-Jones who was a co-author on an Angewandte article presenting a study of unprecedented reactivity of dinuclear non-heme MnII–thiolate complexes with O2, and Lacy Douglas helped develop new materials for solar cell production. After their iREU experience, this cohort prepared and gave an in-person oral presentation at the 2018 ACS National Meeting in New Orleans.  The presentation entitled “The Student Participant Perspective:  Enhancing Undergraduate Research Through International Experiences” was collectively authored by Sarah Hodges, Maggie T. Fox, Nettie Brown, Aurelie Niyongabo, Jessica Flores, Rosa A. Perez, Jose A. Rosales, K. Anjulique Jones and Anthony Keys.

     The 2018 cohort was a dynamic group of students with several members publishing results from their experiences and most have given at least one presentation or poster at a conference.  In addition, the PI’s Randy Duran and David Spivak along with Alison Satake wrote a chapter in NSF’s 2018 publication entitled “LSAMP A Program Modelling Group Impact” by Art Hicks, entitled “Strengthening a Global LSAMP Research Workforce in France: The NSF LSAMP/Chemistry International REU”. Several of the 2019 participants presented their research at the 257th - 259th ACS National Meetings. Because of the COVID pandemic, the program was suspended for 2020 and 2021, and the program was extended to 2022 to finish.

     Pre-departure meetings were held for each cohort before they traveled to France, and the 2017 meeting was actually held at the French Embassy in Washington D.C. hosted by Dr Minh Ha Pham, the Science Consul of the French Embassy; where all participants, some mentors, alumni and administrators (shown in photo “4”), spent 2 days discussing this NSF iREU program informing the students about their upcoming experience through briefings on best practices in international research, personal security, and opportunities in Europe by the State Department and the French Embassy officials. Afterward, the pre-departure meetings were web based that allowed participation of each of the iREU, including previous participants who provided invaluable personal experiences. Students provided weekly updates to the PI covering both the research progress and any cultural experience in France and other European countries.

    The iREU program also co-organized a “French American Workshop” in France during most summers (for example, see photo “5”). The workshops ran for 2 or 3 days and involved 80-100 other STEM students from the French institutions, faculty, and scientists.  Each of these meetings featured a variety of presentations, poster sessions, and panels designed to benefit the participating students and to make connections between the US community represented and a broad range of European scientists. 

     Overall, this NSF iREU program provided high quality research experiences from a range of underrepresented minority students recruited from all over the United States.  The French collaborators were among the most talented researchers and institutions in France, and both the iREU and the French students/mentors learned a lot about each other’s culture and scientific approaches.  In fact, aspects of diversity and women in international research education learned from this iREU program were published in 2 publications by the PI David Spivak along with coworkers (J. Chem. Educ. 2022, 99, 104; Front. Educ. 2021, 6:674673).
